Subjective: Sore throat for 3 days; unbearable pain on swallowing. Fever started this morning. Preceded by a cough last week, now resolved. Used paracetamol and ibuprofen with poor relief. No shortness of breath, no runny nose. History of sore throat years ago; treated with antibiotics once as a child. Friend recently had a peritonsillar abscess. Concern: Worried about having an abscess. Request: Thinks she needs antibiotics.
Objective: Temp: 38.3Â°C. SpO2: 98%. Ears: Left TM normal, air-filled. Right ear canal with mild redness, TM normal. Neck: Small, non-pathological submandibular lymph nodes. Throat: Uvula median. Pharyngeal arch slightly red. Tonsils bilaterally enlarged with some slough, not kissing. No signs of abscess. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, vesicular breath sounds, no added sounds.
Assessment: Acute pharyngitis, likely viral etiology. Peritonsillar abscess ruled out.
Plan: Explanation: Reassured condition is likely viral and self-limiting; antibiotics not indicated and offer minimal benefit. Reassured no signs of abscess. Meds: Continue Paracetamol up to 4x/day for pain/fever; add Ibuprofen 400mg up to 3x/day if needed. Advice: Maintain hydration; cold drinks or popsicles for symptomatic relief. Safety Netting: Return if condition worsens, develops shortness of breath, or unable to swallow.
